snippet: Telling financial institutions to set aside a larger capital cushion is the best way to avoid another meltdown.
abstract: Editorial scores banks for fighting a proposal from regulators to replace credit rating agencies with objective criteria to determine the financial soundness of banks' loans and investments; notes that banks are particularly concerned about the criteria for capital buffers against securitized assets; argues that the cost of bigger capital buffers may not be zero, but it is surely less than the cost of another financial meltdown.
lead_paragraph: Telling financial institutions to set aside a larger capital cushion is the best way to avoid another meltdown.
